Result.Title: Condor-G: A Computation Management Agent for Multi-Institutional Grids

Result.Title: Distributed computing in practice: the Condor experience

Result.Title: Matchmaking: Distributed Resource Management for High Throughput Computing

Result.Title: The HiPAC project: combining active databases and timing constraints

Result.Title: Pegasus: Mapping Scientific Workflows onto the Grid

Result.Abstract: We investigate two schemes for placing data on multiple disks. Result.Abstract: Earlier studies have observed that in moderately-loaded real-time database systems, using an Earliest Deadline policy to schedule tasks results in the fewest missed deadlines. When the real-time system is overloaded, however, an Earliest Deadline schedule performs worse than most other policies. This is due to Earliest Deadline giving the highest priority to transactions that are close to missing their deadlines.
Result.Title: Earliest Deadline Scheduling for Real-Time Database Systems

Result.Title: On being optimistic about real-time constraints

Result.Title: BIRCH: A New Data Clustering Algorithm and Its Applications

Result.Title: Data Access Scheduling in Firm Real-Time Database Systems

Result.Title: Transactional client-server cache consistency: alternatives and performance

Result.Title: The Impact of Autocorrelation on Queuing Systems

Result.Title: Deploying Virtual Machines as Sandboxes for the Grid

Result.Abstract: The Open Science Grid (OSG) provides a distributed facility where the Consortium members provide guaranteed and opportunistic access to shared computing and storage resources. OSG provides support for and evolution of the infrastructure through activities that cover operations, security, software, troubleshooting, addition of new capabilities, and support for existing and engagement with new communities. The OSG SciDAC-2 project provides specific
Result.Title: The open science grid

Conference.FullName: IEEE International Symposium on High Performance Distributed Computing

Result.Abstract: Data-intensive applications in the Condor High Throughput Computing environment can place heavy demands on network resources for checkpointing and remote data access. We have developed mechanisms to monitor, control, and schedule network usage in Condor. By managing network resources, these mechanisms provide administrative control over Condor's network usage and improve the execution efficiency of Condor applications.
Result.Title: Managing Network Resources in Condor
